metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Patna v. Rani Bhuwaneshwari Kuer

facts.text: Rani Bhuwaneshwari Kuer (assessee) was proprietor of seven-sixteenth share in Tekari Raj, inherited from parents, later acquired major portion of remaining nine-sixteenth share by purchase.
Estate heavily encumbered; assessee executed indenture of trust dated January 20, 1941, conveying Tekari Raj and certain zamindari properties to named trustees to liquidate debts.
Principal beneficiaries under deed: assessee, her husband, and five sons, after payment of debts.
Clause 23: Trustees to divide surplus net rents, issues, profits in proportions set out.
Clauses 24 and 25: Devolution of beneficial interest on death of beneficiaries.

Clause 41: After payment of debts in Sch. D, settlor entitled to make permanent trust for Tekari Forts maintenance, Durga Puja, etc.; if settlor dies before, trustees to set apart property yielding Rs. 20,000 net income for those purposes.
Clause 42: Trust terminates after payment of Sch. D debts or death of last son, whichever last occurs.
Clause 43: Challenge to 1939 Indenture forfeits beneficiary rights; breach excludes beneficiary; settlor may revoke or vary during life, but not before Sch. D debts paid.
Deed modified by rectification dated December 22, 1941: Assessee has power to revoke or vary during lifetime, but not affecting Sch. D debts.

Deed of amendment dated January 12, 1942: Cancelled/amended various clauses; para 23: surplus divided in seven equal shares; para 24: on son's death, share to heirs; para 42 modified: terminates after debts or extinguishment of Thicca leases to Maharajadhiraj of Darbhanga or Capt. Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narain Singh, whichever last; para 42a: then partition; para 45: settlement permanent, unalterable, irrevocable re interests created, until debts discharged and leases effective.
Thicca lease to Maharajadhiraj of Darbhanga till 1965; to Capt. Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narain Singh till 1954.
Assessment year 1947-48: ITO rejected assessee's contention, taxed trust income as assessee's under s.16(1)(c); confirmed by AAC.
Tribunal reversed: not revocable trust under s.16(1)(c).

Patna High Court under s.66(2): Referred questions on revocability and taxability; held revocable but third proviso applies, income to other beneficiaries not taxable as assessee's till revocation power arises; assessee taxable on her beneficiary share.
Commissioner appealed to SC with special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the trust created by the assessee is a revocable trust within the meaning of s.16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act?
Whether the income from the trust property can be deemed income of the assessee under s.16(1)(c)?
Applicability of third proviso to s.16(1)(c): whether income to other beneficiaries exempt if not revocable for >6 years and settlor derives no direct/indirect benefit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trust revocable within six years as in fact revoked (citing 1946 deed), or per terms revocable within six years.
Third proviso does not apply as assessee derives direct benefit as beneficiary.
Third proviso applies only to actual settlements under principal clause, not deemed revocable under first proviso.

respondent_arguments.text: No revocation within six years; power not exercisable till debts paid and Thicca leases expired (post-1954/1965).
Third proviso excludes income to other beneficiaries; settlor's own share taxable separately.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of actual revocation within six years not raised earlier, unsustainable; recitals in 1946 deed do not indicate revocation.
Per cl.45 (1942 amendment), irrevocable till debts discharged and Thicca leases effective (till 1954/1965); not revocable within six years.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revocation power not exercisable within six years.

court_reasoning.text: Third proviso has two conditions: not revocable >6 years, and settlor no direct/indirect benefit from that income; applies to exclude other beneficiaries' income, not settlor's own.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso excludes only income to 'any person' other than settlor.

court_reasoning.text: Third proviso applies even to settlements deemed revocable under first proviso; scheme per Kania J. in Ramji Keshavji.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisos explanatory; third proviso operates post first.

holdings.text: Trust not revocable within six years per s.16(1)(c); third proviso applies to exempt income to other beneficiaries from inclusion in assessee's income.
Assessee liable to tax on her own beneficiary share.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of s.16(1)(c) provisos explained by Kania J.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems settlor's income from revocable settlements; third proviso exempts income to others if not revocable >6 years and no settlor benefit.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Patna High Court: trust income to beneficiaries other than assessee not includible in her income under third proviso to s.16(1)(c); assessee taxable on her share.
outcome.relief_granted: Income of other beneficiaries excluded from assessee's total income.

key_quotes.text: "the third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) does not operate to exclude the income which the settlor receives as a beneficiary, from liability to income-tax it merely excludes that part of the income which is under the deed of settlement given to another person"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "By cl. 45 of the deed of amendment the right of revocation was not exercisable till the Thicca leases... remained good and effective"
key_quotes.speaker: court
